title: Friday, 14th December 2018
bodyHTML:

nightingale20201 morning all

Worries about delays and stuff were apparently a factor in GVC's slump over the past couple of months.

Excel Developer China tariff cut from 40% to 15% on cars simply dials it back to where it started, no?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Here's Citi to summarise where we are.

BE11:25am

Given the cross-parliamentary approval there has been for this gaming machine regulation, we expect the vote to be uncontentious. This is a significant positive catalyst for GVC shares as, if the legislation is approved, it will be enacted before the 28 March 2019 deadline for the CVR payout. This would remove the “CVR tail risk” that has recently kept some investors on the sidelines, in our view. The c£676m CVR would have been paid out from GVC to Ladbrokes Coral shareholders, representing 18% of GVC’s market cap.

BE11:25am

It was never really explained to me why GVC structured the Ladbrokes deal with a contingent value right rather than just holding off until it had regulatory clarity.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Why the rush? What was wrong with the core business?

BE11:26am

Anyway, Barclays also buying ahead of the vote.

BE11:27am

Perversely (given the material negative impact this change in law has on cash flows), this is the news GVC and GVC’s shareholders have been waiting for. It means that GVC will not have to pay the c. £700m CVR payment. This issue has been a major overhang on the share price and as such, we expect a relief rally after the recent share price softness.

MOS GAM, what's so bad ? Settled yesterday and now down 15% again
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Though it moves on from there ......

zho Excel - yes
BE11:28am

With two potential positives.

BE11:28am

Firstly, GVC said it will announce something regarding the contract between Ladbrokes Coral and Playtech (we think that something would be an early termination of the contract thus bringing forward the synergies from the contract at least one year earlier than expected).

zho .... but it is a conciliatory move
11:28 am
Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 416.80, down 1.6 (-0.38%), High: 421.00, Low: 413.80, Volume: 450.24k
BE11:28am

And ....

BE11:29am

Secondly, GVC’s CEO, Kenny Alexander, was bullish on the Q3 conference call saying that despite the very tough Q417 comp, if Gross Win Margins in Q4 are normal, he would hope to grow Online NGR in Q4 (our forecasts, which are broadly consensual, assume -2% Online NGR in Q4). Our recent Oddschecker data suggests Gross Win Margins in Q4 so far have actually been slightly better than average (see Oddschecker Nov Data, 12/12/18). So we see the potential for an upgrade. After the sell-off, and with the CVR overhang all but out of the way, we expect to see GVC rally from here.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Investec also buying GVC, but its note's just new forecasts really, so I'll ignore that one.

undefined

This is -- in theory -- on the auditor report into the £495m army recruitment scheme

BE11:36am

So as per Capita's results in August, management said it had reset the Army contract .....

BE11:37am

We're not yet meeting contractual targets for the Army recruitment contract. However, the new recruiting software, DRS, is now working. It's in
place, and we have seen an encouraging response to recent recruitment campaigns, and I can share with you that the regular soldier application
is now at a 5-year seasonal high. We have set -- we have reset, sorry, our partnership with the Army at a very senior level and both parties remain
committed to making a success of the contract. For example, the Army is proactively reviewing selected entry policies in order to increase the
potential pool of candidates we can attract. And whilst we're currently making a small profit on this contract, we're not generating the kind of
return we should and will not do so until we are delivering against the recruitment targets.

BornCynic Almost as good as loosing £4.2 billion on selling off the military houses to Guy Hands.
11:37 am
BE11:37am

That was CEO Jonathan Lewis at the results conference call back in August.

Soundbuy As its the last session I'm consuming a brewdog IPA........a freebie I may add........should have put up some ballons...
BE11:38am

Suggesting that there's no liability here beyond reputation.

RuminationsOn On Army recruitment - Army has been below recruiting targets every year since mid-1980's (closure of pits, plant and ship building is conducive to recruitment). Blaming Capita on the youth of today not wanting to live in a cold wet trench with equipment designed in the 1970's and made in the 80's so we can fund Trident is a little rich
BE11:39am

Though as no services analysts seem to be at work this morning, that's just my reading. If I get anything useful before midday I'll share.

BE11:43am

alue potential is extremely attractive but macro risks are exceptionally high. Over the last few years, while there has been pressure on margins and the market in London and the South-East at the higher end has slowed, the sector has generally defied the macro doomsayers and continued to deliver strong profits, attractive dividends and net asset growth. In 2018, share prices performed very poorly as Brexit related macro fears intensified and the autumn selling season looked a bit wanting, particularly at higher price points. We look into 2019 with the sector pricing in significant risk and presenting a very attractive potential value opportunity assuming we avoid a painful housing recession. For us, with strong balance sheets, capital discipline, a supportive land market and extension to Help to Buy, the key issue remains macro. Our crude sensitivity analysis in this note shows that the sector appears to be broadly pricing in a 5% fall in house prices and a 10% fall in volumes and if the actual outcome for 2019, is at or close to current consensus expectations, we would expect a sharp value rally; we have not changed estimates but see downside risk if the continuing political drama spills into next year. Our top picks are Bellway, MJ Gleeson and Persimmon with more caution around Crest Nicholson and Telford Homes.

Mouselet Today I have a Christmassy supply-chain question. How on Earth do I work out who it is that makes the machines that make the reversible fish-scale sequin fabric which is all the rage this Christmas?
urgeview Any chance of some volumes for next week's ftse review ?
11:43 am
BE11:44am

Clearly the macro outlook remains the big call for 2019 and there is an unusual lack of visibility. Consensus forecasts point to low single digit percentage GDP growth with unemployment and interest rates remaining at low levels. Assuming that the macro backdrop remains relatively supportive, we would expect the new housing market to deliver modest volume growth of c.+1-2% combined with modest house price inflation of c.+1-2%. Build cost inflation is expected to ease a little to c.+3-4% and generally flat to easing land costs coming through. The live risk for us relates to sales rates, particularly in the Spring selling season next year and this is likely to be driven by confidence and employment expectations.

Mouselet alibaba gives me umpteen Chinese resellers of the fabric, but I am interested in the maker of the machine that makes the fabric
BE11:44am

Sector's at 1.3 times with an average dividend yield of c.9%, they say.

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 235.40, no change, High: 240.89, Low: 230.50, Volume: 513.06k
BE11:51am

Oh, and while it was yesterday, it's worth quoting the Peel Hunt downgrade of Sports Direct.

BE11:52am

Today’s figures were solid given the circumstances but we have run out of patience with the lack of visibility on strategy. Yes it’s all very interesting to hear a deep dive on Flannels, but investors required chapter and verse on the plans for House of Fraser, as opposed to an extremely optimistic pledge for it to break even next year. It’s the same with the core business: yes, the elevation programme is working but what about the non-elevated stores? What’s the plan for them? Clearly current trading is very poor, as it is everywhere, and our new forecasts reflect a tough Christmas ahead for both the core stores and HOF (our numbers now reflect the HOF losses, there’s no change to underlying EBITDA expectations). The shares’ valuation suggests forecast momentum here, and we are no longer convinced that this exists. We move back to Hold (from Add), TP 260p.

11:51 am

BE12:03pm

Management flagged hospitality purchases so it's not as leftfield as it looks.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Morgan Stanley:

BE12:03pm

Over the past few years, LVMH management had suggested that the Group was looking at potential acquisitions in the luxury hospitality segment, so this would be in line with the company's stated strategy and should not come as too much of a surprise. We believe that part of the rational for the transaction is that the growth in the luxury 'experience' sector is expected to remain solid in the coming years.

Tom Dalgleish we're somewhat late cycle when luxury goods buy outlets and boot the competition
BE12:04pm

From a financial perspective, Belmond's EV accounts for 2.2% of LVMH's market capitalization and based on consensus forecasts for Belmond we expect the transaction would be EPS neutral in 2019. From a return on capital employed standpoint, this should be dilutive to LVMH's ROIC (c.100 bps to 19.6% pretax for 2019e based on
consensus forecasts for Belmond); however, this will be greatly dependent on LVMH's future intentions regarding a sales and leaseback of Belmond's highly valued real estate assets (based on its prior strategy we believe that LVMH is unlikely to make significant changes to Belmond's real estate strategy). While this transaction should not come as too much of a surprise to investors, we suspect the stock could be under a little pressure given the lack of synergies, lower return profile of Belmond compared to LVMH's and the now reduced probability that LVMH would return cash to shareholders in the coming quarters.

sprout @Tom - isn't it more because people are starting to have enough 'stuff' and now spend on experiences. Especially the Chinese.
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Oh, they're the Hotel Cipriani in Venice as well. That's a bad place.

BE12:05pm

Berenberg:

BE12:05pm

Through this acquisition, LVMH will significantly increase its presence
in the ultimate luxury hotel world, where it is already present via its ownership of the Cheval Blanc maisons and Bvlgari hotels. We note that LVMH has not yet disclosed the potential financial impact of the transaction, which based on the available Bloomberg estimates is fairly insignificant, implying less than 1% EPS accretion in 2019E.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

While some investors may question the acquisition, which appears to lie outside LVMH group’s core operations, we believe it is consistent with its long-term strategy focused on offering the consumer a full spectrum of luxury experience. Importantly, the deal does not affect group’s significant balance sheet firepower, which we estimate now at c€25bn (assuming c2.0x net debt/EBITDA) and expect to be deployed in the next 12-18 months, as we foresee an uptick in M&A activity in the sector
